M4A2 Sherman.note: American Sherman tanks received March 1943 refit, replacing Crusader/Valentine losses from Kasserine Pass

Crusader Mk III.note: Remaining Crusaders kept for reconnaissance duties

Ordnance QF 25-pounder Gun-Howitzer.note: Two field regiments (12th RHA, 152nd Field Regiment) with 24 guns each

supply_logistics.supply_status: ADEQUATE for defensive operations, STRAINED for offensive. Post-Kasserine Pass refit (Feb-March 1943) restored strength. Sherman tank deliveries from US stocks. Primary constraint: fuel delivery from Algerian ports (400km). Tunisia Campaign mud (Jan-March) limits vehicle mobility. Competing with American II Corps and British 78th Division for port capacity at Bone.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Tunisian hills and valleys - mud restricts tank operations. Mountainous terrain near Thala and Kasserine Pass. Improved roads in coastal areas, poor tracks inland.

subordinate_units.equipment: 192 tanks (156x M4A2 Sherman, 24x Crusader Mk III, 12x Valentine Mk IX)
subordinate_units.note: Three tank regiments: 16th/5th Lancers, 17th/21st Lancers, 2nd Lothians and Border Horse. Re-equipped with American M4A2 Sherman tanks March 1943 after Kasserine Pass losses. Sherman superiority: 75mm gun, better armor than Crusader.

Guards Brigade replaced 38th (Irish) Brigade (transferred to 78th Division February 1943). Elite infantry battalions provide high-quality infantry support for armoured operations. Three Guards battalions motorised.

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 12th Regiment, Royal Horse Artillery (Honourable Artillery Company)
subordinate_units.note: 24x Ordnance QF 25-pounders, self-propelled and towed variants
Divisional reconnaissance regiment with Humber and Daimler armoured cars. Scout ahead of main armoured formations.
Three field squadrons plus bridging, mine clearance, and demolition troops
Radio, telephone, dispatch communications for division
RASC transport companies, RAOC ordnance, REME workshops, RAMC field ambulances, military police, postal services

tactical_doctrine.role: Armoured division - spearhead of British First Army final Tunisia offensive (Operation Vulcan, May 1943). Division blooded at Kasserine Pass (February 1943), refitted with American Sherman tanks (March 1943), designated spearhead of IX Corps breakthrough to Tunis (May 1943). Captured Tunis 7 May 1943, accepted surrender of German 90th Light Division.
special_capabilities: American Sherman M4A2 tanks (March 1943 refit) - 75mm gun, superior armor to Crusader/Valentine
Combat-proven - Kasserine Pass defensive battles, Tunisia campaign November 1942 - May 1943
Elite Guards Brigade infantry (replaced 38th Irish Brigade February 1943) - high morale, well-trained
IX Corps spearhead - fresh corps formed for final offensive
Mobile combined arms - tanks, motorised Guards infantry, self-propelled artillery
Experienced reconnaissance - Derbyshire Yeomanry veterans of Tunisia fighting
tactical_innovations: Sherman tank superiority - 75mm gun penetrates most German armor at range
Combined arms coordination perfected through 6 months Tunisia campaign combat
Breakthrough tactics - concentrated armour punch supported by Guards infantry
Rapid exploitation - captured Tunis within 48 hours of breakthrough
Integration of 17-pounder anti-tank guns (early 1943) - heavy AT capability
known_issues: Kasserine Pass losses (19-25 February 1943) - heavy tank casualties defending Thala against 10. Panzer-Division and 21. Panzer-Division
Sherman M4A2 diesel engines - less familiar to British crews than petrol engines (requires crew retraining)
Transition from 38th Irish to Guards Brigade (February 1943) - new unit integration requires coordination practice
Tunisia mud (January-March) severely limits tank mobility - Sherman heavy, vulnerable to bogging
Only one infantry brigade - insufficient for sustained combined operations (standard armoured division has motor brigade only)
Logistics strain - Algerian ports 400km distant, competing with American II Corps for supplies
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: LIMITED - Division trained for desert warfare (1940-1942 UK training) but Tunisia Campaign is NOT desert. Terrain: hills, valleys, farmland, mud. Weather: cold, wet, muddy (winter/spring). Tactics adapted to European-style terrain and weather. Sherman tanks better suited to Tunisia terrain than lighter Crusaders.

scenario_suitability: Battle of Kasserine Pass (19-25 February 1943) - Defense of Thala against Panzer counteroffensive
Tunisia Campaign January-March 1943 - stalemate and refit period
Operation Vulcan final offensive (6-13 May 1943) - IX Corps spearhead breakthrough
Breakthrough to Tunis (7 May 1943) - division captures Axis capital
Surrender of 90th Light Division - division accepts German capitulation
Armoured division vs Panzer/Panzergrenadier - Sherman vs Panzer IV/Tiger
wargaming_data.experience_level: Veteran (combat experience since November 1942 Operation Torch, Kasserine Pass February 1943)
special_rules: Sherman M4A2 superiority: +1 armor save vs 50mm/75mm guns, 75mm gun +1 penetration vs medium armor
Combat veteran: +1 to morale checks (Tunisia campaign experience)
Guards Brigade elite infantry: +1 to infantry assault/defense rolls
IX Corps spearhead: +1 to breakthrough/exploitation operations
Allied air superiority: -1 to Axis movement/supply in daylight hours
Kasserine Pass experience: +1 vs German Panzer tactics (learned enemy methods)
Mud penalty (Q1 only): -1 movement for all tracked vehicles (Tunisia winter rains)
17-pounder AT guns: Penetrates Tiger I front armor at 1000m (rare heavy AT capability)
historical_engagements: Run for Tunis (14-28 November 1942) - first Tunisia battles, checked by Axis
Battle of Kasserine Pass (19-25 February 1943) - defense of Thala, heavy losses but held
Refit March 1943 - Sherman M4A2 tanks replace Crusader/Valentine losses
Operation Vulcan (6-13 May 1943) - IX Corps final offensive, division spearhead
Capture of Tunis (7 May 1943) - division enters capital, first Allied unit
Surrender of 90th Light Division (12 May 1943) - division accepts capitulation
Tunisia Campaign ends 13 May 1943 - 250,000 Axis prisoners (Tunis/Bizerta)

source: British Army Lists 1943 Q1 - divisional organization
TM30-410 British Army Handbook 1942 - armoured division establishment
Battle Orders 028: Desert Rats - British 8th Army structure
Kasserine Pass battle reports - February 1943 casualties
Sherman tank delivery records - US Lend-Lease to British First Army March 1943
Guards Brigade transfer records - 38th Irish to 78th Division, Guards to 6th Armoured February 1943

chief_of_staff.name.reason: Chief of Staff name not available in accessible sources for Q1 1943
chief_of_staff.name.mitigation: UK National Archives divisional war diaries would contain staff roster

regimental_commanders.reason: Brigade commanders identified (Gough-Calthorpe, Russell) but artillery/engineer/signals commanders not in accessible sources
regimental_commanders.mitigation: Regimental association records or National Archives

exact_tank_numbers_per_regiment.reason: Total Sherman strength known (~156) but distribution across 16th/5th Lancers, 17th/21st Lancers, 2nd Lothians not specified
exact_tank_numbers_per_regiment.estimate_method: Standard British armoured regiment: 52 tanks (4 squadrons x 13 tanks). 3 regiments = 156 Shermans total.
exact_tank_numbers_per_regiment.mitigation: Regimental war diaries would show exact squadron allocations

notes: Q1 1943: Tunisia Campaign - defensive battles, refit, preparation for final offensive
Major change from Q4 1942: Sherman M4A2 tanks replace Crusader/Valentine (March 1943)
Major change from Q4 1942: Guards Brigade replaces 38th Irish Brigade (February 1943)
Kasserine Pass (Feb 1943): Division suffered heavy tank losses defending Thala
IX Corps assignment: Fresh corps formed for final offensive (May 1943)
Combat experience: 6 months Tunisia fighting (November 1942 - May 1943)
Tier 1 classification: 85% confidence, production ready for wargaming scenarios

commander.name: Major-General Charles Keightley
commander.previous_service: Commanded division since January 1942, led through Operation Torch and Tunisia Campaign

command.headquarters_location: Tunisia - IX Corps sector, preparing for Operation Vulcan final offensive
